data: NICU Chest Tube Insertion
Patient Care
Refer to NICU Vital Sign Monitoring Guideline
Vital Signs
Increase frequency of vital signs as per policy
Chest Tube Care
Suction:  -10 cm H20 suction
Suction:  -20 cm H20 suction
Suction: No suction, Special Instructions: underwater seal
Chest Tube Care
Suction:  -10 cm H20 suction
Suction:  -20 cm H20 suction
Suction: No suction, Special Instructions: underwater seal
Continuous Infusions
Conditional Order - Ongoing
If/when chest tube losses are greater than ____ mL in ____ hours, then replace losses 1:1 with sodium chloride 0.9% continuous infusion
If/when chest tube losses are greater than ____ mL in ____ hours, then replace losses 1:1 with sodium chloride 0.45% continuous infusion
If/when chest tube losses are greater than ____ mL in ____ hours, then replace losses 1:1 with Albumin Transfusion
If/when chest tube losses are greater than ____ mL in ____ hours, then replace losses 1:1 with Plasma Transfusion
sodium chloride 0.9% (NS) continuous infusion
Replace chest tube losses 1:1, IV, drug form: bag
sodium chloride 0.45% (1/2NS) continuous infusion
Replace chest tube losses 1:1, IV, drug form: bag
PED/NEO TM Albumin Transfusion (Module)
PED/NEO TM Plasma Transfusion (Frozen Plasma / FFP) (Module)

acetaminophen

10 mg/kg, rectal, q4h interval, PRN pain, drug form: oral liq
15 mg/kg, rectal, q6h interval, PRN pain, drug form: oral liq

For morphine continuous IV infusions:  - Suggested starting dose for patients less than or equal to 27 weeks: 10 mcg/kg/h  - Suggested starting dose for patients 28 to 31 weeks: 15 mcg/kg/h  - Suggested starting dose for patients greater than or equal to 32 weeks: 20 mcg/kg/h
For continuous opioid infusions, confirm with bedside nurse or clinical pharmacist if unsure which volume to select
